intro: Lupinus luthereaui, commonly known as the coastal lupine, is a flowering plant native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its tall, upright growth habit and clusters of blue to purple pea-like flowers. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal dunes and open grasslands. Lupinus luthereaui plays an important ecological role by fixing nitrogen in the soil, benefiting surrounding plant life.
